item.content:encoded:
Are you passionate about international law, humanitarian protection and advancing sustainable development? The Apply for Junior Collaborator – Institutional Engagement & Development Actors (IIHL) represents a unique opportunity to join a world-renowned organisation shaping global policy and partnerships in refugee law and migration law.

Position Title

– Junior Collaborator – Institutional Engagement & Development Actors
– Department of International Refugee Law and Migration Law
– International Institute of Humanitarian Law (IIHL), Sanremo, Italy (Remote)

Application Deadline

Applications Close on 5th March 2026 (Rome CET time)

Work Location

Remote / Home-based (with reliable internet)
Travel to Sanremo (Italy), Geneva (Switzerland) or other duty stations may be required and fully covered by IIHL.

Contract Details

  • Contract Type: 6-month collaboration contract

  • Remuneration: ~€500 per month

  • Scholarships: Complimentary access to Department’s online learning courses

  • Hours: Full-time remote role with possible attendance at meetings in Rome CET time zone

Role Overview

Under guidance from the Head of the Institutional Engagement Unit, the Junior Collaborator will:

• Conduct research on development actors and humanitarian–development–peace nexus issues
• Map partnership and funding opportunities with global development institutions
• Support online and in-person capacity-sharing and learning initiatives
• Track partnerships and contribute to key strategic work of the Department

This role is ideal for early-career professionals seeking first-hand experience with international organisations and a gateway to future roles in humanitarian law and development sectors.

Key Responsibilities

1. Mapping & Research

  • Research development actors including governmental, UN, regional, and financial institutions

  • Identify partnership and funding possibilities for capacity building and strategic projects.

  • Analyze trends in protection, displacement, and sustainable responses.

2. Support & Outreach

  • Support capacity-sharing initiatives like online courses.

  • Maintain and update the Department’s internal partnerships tracker.

  • Assist with documentation and reporting on development engagement activities.

Qualifications & Skills Required

Mandatory
1. University degree in Social Sciences, International Relations, Political Science, Economics, Development Studies, or related field.
2. Strong organizational, written, and oral communication skills.
3. Fluency in English (other UN languages are a plus).
4. Commitment to humanitarian and protection work in displacement contexts.

Desirable
1. Experience with international development projects or institutions.
2. Familiarity with refugee, migration, and statelessness law frameworks.
3. Knowledge of instructional design or online capacity-building platforms.

Why This Opportunity Matters

This role is strategically positioned at the intersection of humanitarian action, development, and global partnerships. By focusing on development actors, you’ll engage with institutions shaping responses to displacement, resilience, and global cooperation — all while enhancing your professional credentials in a globally respected institution.

Benefits of the Position

• Professional experience with an international legal & humanitarian organisation
• Exposure to global development and refugee protection coordination
• Career development through learning scholarships
• Remote flexibility with optional travel fully funded by IIHL
• Priority consideration for future roles within the Department

How to Apply

Submit the following through the official IIHL Careers Portal:

 Required Documents:
1. Updated CV
2. Motivation Letter

Apply here

Tip: The Institute may start interviews before the deadline if strong candidates are identified early.

The International Institute of Humanitarian Law embraces diversity and inclusion — all qualified applicants are encouraged to apply regardless of gender, nationality, ethnicity, religion, disability, age, sexual orientation, or background. Applications from individuals with forced displacement and statelessness experiences are especially welcome.

For more information visit here

item.content:encoded:
If you’re an ambitious researcher looking to pursue a world-class PhD in Economics, the Cologne Graduate School in Management, Economics and Social Sciences (CGS) at the University of Cologne (UoC) is one of the most competitive and rewarding graduate destinations in Europe.

Why This Programme is a Top Global Choice

The PhD Programme in Economics at CGS/UoC stands out because it offers:

  • A fully English-taught, research-driven curriculum with international faculty.

  • Rigorous training that prepares you for academic careers and top research jobs worldwide.

  • Structured supervision and research opportunities across economics, econometrics, political economy, behavioral economics, and more.

  • A vibrant research ecosystem with connections to major research centers like the Cluster of Excellence “ECONtribute: Markets & Public Policy” and external partners like the Max Planck Institute.

  • No tuition and multiple funding avenues including fully funded PhD positions, scholarships, and research assistant roles.

Funding, Scholarships & Benefits

1. Full PhD Funding

  • Fully funded doctoral positions through CGS or partners.

  • Funding typically covers living expenses during the PhD stage.

2. Stipends for M.Sc. Stage

  • A limited number of scholarships available for exceptional M.Sc. students.

Who Can Apply: Eligibility & Qualifications

 1. Applicants with a Bachelor’s Degree

You can enter the programme via the M.Sc. Economic Research (First Stage), designed to bridge undergraduate preparation to doctoral research.
Ideal if:

  • Your Bachelor’s is in Economics, Econometrics, Finance, or related fields.

  • You rank among the top graduates in your cohort.

Outcome:Completing the M.Sc. successfully gives you direct access to the doctoral (PhD) stage.

 2. Applicants with a Master’s Degree

Students holding a master’s degree in Economics or a closely related discipline can apply directly to the PhD Stage.

Strong qualification signals include:

  • Proven research interest or thesis evidence.

  • Academic excellence (top GPA/grades).

  • Clear match between your research interests and faculty expertise.

Additional Training or Course Work

  • If your Master’s does not include sufficient Economics coursework, you may need up to one year of additional courses drawn from the M.Sc. curriculum.

Application Checklist & Submission Requirements

To build a strong application, prepare the following:

Standard Application Materials

  •  Certified degree transcripts and diplomas (Bachelor’s/Master’s)

  •  Detailed CV with academic highlights.

  •  Research proposal (ideally aligned with faculty research)

  •  Recommendation letters (academic)

  •  Motivation letter explaining your fit for research.

  •  Proof of English proficiency (if not from an English-medium degree). (site may specify requirements when applications open)

Apply here

Application Deadlines & Intake Periods

 PhD Programme (with Integrated M.Sc. Option)

  • 15th March 2026 for PhD

  • 31st March 2026 for Msc

  •  Programme starts every October

Tip: Mark mid-January to early February in your calendar to check for open application calls.

Strategic Tips to Win Admission

• Start Preparing Early – applications open January; deadlines are strict.
• Match faculty research – show clear alignment between your research vision and CGS strengths.
• Solid research proposal boosts competitiveness in this highly selective programme.
• Strong academic record is essential, especially at the master’s level.

Other Funding Opportunities

  • External fellowships such as EWI Fellowship for Energy Economics (requiring separate application).

  • Some doctoral positions are offered jointly with partner research institutions (e.g Max Planck Institute).

Additional Perks

  • Extensive conference funding and research stay support.

  • Opportunities for joint publications and collaborative research.

  • No tuition fees — only a nominal semester fee

The PhD Programme in Economics at the Cologne Graduate School is a globally respected research destination — and for good reason. With no tuition, funded PhD positions, a strong international research network, and excellent post-graduate prospects, it’s a transformative step for future economists and academic leaders.

For more information visit here

item.content:encoded:
Are you ready to launch a meaningful career in education while making a direct impact in high-need communities? The NYC Teaching Fellows Program 2026 offers a highly selective, fully supported pathway to become a certified teacher in New York City Public Schools by Fall 2026.

Designed for talented professionals and recent graduates from diverse backgrounds, the program prepares participants to teach in critical shortage subject areas such as math, science, special education, and bilingual education—while earning a full-time salary and working toward a subsidized master’s degree.

If you are passionate about educational equity, student success, and leadership in urban education, this opportunity could redefine your career trajectory.

About NYC Teaching Fellows

NYC Teaching Fellows is a rigorous alternative certification program operated by NYC Public Schools—the largest public school system in the United States, serving approximately 1 million students across more than 1,600 schools.

The program recruits individuals committed to addressing educational inequities in underserved communities. Fellows receive intensive training, ongoing coaching, and professional development while working full-time as teachers.

By Fall 2026, selected candidates will be placed in NYC Public Schools classrooms and begin their careers as certified educators.

Program Structure and Timeline

Summer 2026 – Intensive Pre-Service Training

Participants begin with a 7-week intensive summer training program designed to build foundational teaching competencies, including:

  • Instructional planning

  • Classroom management

  • Curriculum development

  • Student assessment strategies

  • Equity-centered pedagogy

Fellows receive a stipend during this training period.

September 2026 – Full-Time Teaching Placement

In Fall 2026, Fellows:

  • Begin teaching full-time in NYC Public Schools

  • Earn a starting salary of $71,314+ per year

  • Receive full employee benefits

  • Continue working toward initial teaching certification

Graduate Education Component

Participants simultaneously pursue a subsidized master’s degree in education at a partner institution.

This dual-track model allows Fellows to:

  • Gain hands-on classroom experience

  • Complete graduate coursework

  • Earn certification

  • Develop advanced pedagogical skills

Compensation and Benefits

The NYC Teaching Fellows program offers a competitive financial and professional package:

Starting Salary

$71,314+ per year as a full-time NYC Public Schools teacher

Summer Training Stipend

Participants receive financial support during the 7-week summer training period.

Full Benefits Package

  • Medical insurance

  • Dental insurance

  • Vision insurance

  • Pension plan

  • 401(k)

  • Commuter benefits

  • Tuition assistance

  • Student loan assistance

Professional Development

  • Ongoing mentorship

  • Coaching support

  • Access to a network of dedicated educators

  • Structured professional growth pathway

High-Need Subject Areas

NYC Teaching Fellows recruits candidates for shortage subject areas, including:

  • Mathematics

  • Science

  • Special Education

  • Bilingual Education

Specific subject eligibility requirements may apply. Applicants are encouraged to review subject-specific criteria HERE.

Who Should Apply?

NYC Teaching Fellows seeks candidates who demonstrate:

  • Commitment to educational equity

  • Resilience and adaptability

  • Growth mindset

  • Passion for student success

  • Willingness to work in high-need communities

Importantly, no prior teaching experience is required.

Eligibility Requirements

To apply for the Fall 2026 cohort, candidates must:

  • Hold a bachelor’s degree by May 31, 2026

  • Have a minimum undergraduate GPA of 2.5

  • Be fluent in written and spoken English

  • Have permanent authorization to work in the United States

  • Never have participated in a program leading to U.S. or Puerto Rico teacher certification

  • Meet additional subject-specific requirements where applicable

Why Choose NYC Public Schools?

NYC Public Schools is the largest public school system in the U.S., employing:

  • 75,000+ teachers

  • Thousands of counselors, social workers, administrators, and staff

The system reflects New York City’s vibrant diversity and is deeply committed to equity, inclusion, and excellence.

By joining NYC Teaching Fellows, participants become part of a workforce dedicated to ensuring every student is seen, supported, and set up to thrive.

Equal Opportunity Employer

The NYC Department of Education is committed to nondiscrimination and equal opportunity in employment and education. Opportunities are provided without regard to race, color, religion, ethnicity, national origin, citizenship status, age, marital status, disability, sexual orientation, gender, military status, or other protected characteristics.

How to Apply

Find the application link HERE.

Click HERE to find the program information.

Interested candidates are encouraged to apply early due to the competitive and highly selective nature of the program.

Discover more job opportunities on OFY HERE.

item.content:encoded:
The 1st Open Call for the Financial Support Program is now open, offering funding to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) that want to leverage downstream space technologies to create environmentally sustainable and circular solutions. This initiative empowers companies to integrate Earth Observation (EO), remote sensing, and satellite navigation data into innovative processes, services, or products that reduce environmental impact.

What the Program Offers

This Financial Support Program provides funding for SMEs to contract External Service Providers who can help design, develop, or implement space-enabled green solutions. These solutions can either:

  • Improve the company’s own internal operations

  • Deliver environmental benefits to customers and end users

Example Use Cases

  • Optimizing internal processes to reduce waste, emissions, or resource consumption

  • Developing products or services for environmental monitoring and resource management

Projects can range from early-stage ideas to fully developed solutions.

Funding Details

  • Total Budget: €1,250,000

  • Number of SMEs Supported: 35

  • Maximum Funding per SME: €50,000

Who Can Apply?

This Open Call is designed for SMEs that:

  • Are based in EU Member States or Horizon Europe Associated Countries

  • Can demonstrate potential to use downstream space data (e.g., EO, remote sensing, satellite navigation) to reduce environmental impact

SME Eligibility Criteria

Applicants must meet the EU SME definition:

  • Fewer than 250 employees

  • Annual turnover not exceeding €50 million OR balance sheet total not exceeding €43 million

Priority Areas

The program gives special attention to solutions that focus on:

  • Circularity, resource efficiency, and waste management

  • Environmentally responsible management of raw materials

  • Advanced environmental monitoring solutions

Why Apply?

This program offers SMEs a unique opportunity to:

  • Access funding for innovation and sustainability

  • Integrate cutting-edge space data technologies

  • Improve environmental performance and competitiveness

  • Build partnerships with specialized service providers

If your business is ready to harness space-enabled data for environmental impact, this is your opportunity to turn your idea into a funded, real-world solution.

How to Apply

Applying is straightforward and completed online through the OnePass platform:

  1. Register or log in on OnePass

  2. Complete your application

  3. Describe your solution and required services from external providers

  4. Submit your application

Once submitted, your application will be evaluated, and selected applicants will be matched with external service providers to implement their projects.

Application Deadline

31 March 2026 at 23:59 CET (Brussels time)

Timeline Overview

  • January 2026: Open Call launch

  • February 2026: First cut-off

  • March 2026: Final application deadline

  • April 2026: Evaluation and selection of first batch of winners

  • Following months: Selection of second batch and project implementation

  • Up to 6 months after signing: Project implementation period

  • Final stage: Review and voucher payment

Support and Guidance

Applicants are encouraged to review the Guide for Applicants carefully before submitting their proposals. The guide explains eligibility, application steps, and evaluation criteria.

For more details about this funding opportunities, click Here.

Start your application today and contribute to a more sustainable, circular future.

Discover more Funding Opportunities.

item.content:encoded:
Are you looking to gain hands-on experience in global development, infrastructure, and international partnerships? The U.S. Trade and Development Agency (USTDA) is offering a range of internship opportunities for motivated students and young professionals eager to contribute to impactful projects in emerging markets.

USTDA plays a key role as the U.S. government’s first mover on critical infrastructure development, helping to advance shared strategic priorities while fostering sustainable economic growth worldwide. Through its internship program, you can work alongside experienced professionals and gain exposure to international development, trade, and policy implementation.

Available Internship Openings

1. Office of Programs Internship

  • Application Period: February 19, 2026 – March 20, 2026

  • Department: Office of Programs

  • Overview:
    Interns in this office will support USTDA’s core project development activities, contributing to initiatives that drive critical infrastructure development in emerging economies.

2. Intern, Office of Administration / Human Resources

  • Application Period: February 19, 2026 – March 20, 2026

  • Department: Office of Administration / HR

  • Overview:
    This role offers experience in organizational operations, talent management, and HR systems that support the agency’s global mission and internal workforce development.

3. Intern, Office of the Chief Information Officer

  • Application Period: February 19, 2026 – March 20, 2026

  • Department: Office of the Chief Information Officer (OCIO)

  • Overview:
    Interns will assist with IT systems, digital infrastructure, and information management, supporting the technological backbone of USTDA’s global operations.

Why Apply?

An internship with USTDA offers you the chance to:

  • Gain real-world experience in international development and trade

  • Work on projects that support infrastructure growth in emerging markets

  • Develop professional skills in policy, administration, technology, and project management

  • Build a global professional network within a U.S. government agency

  • Contribute to meaningful initiatives that drive economic development and sustainability

Application Deadline

All internship applications close on March 20, 2026. Early applications are strongly encouraged.

To apply to any of the internship opportunities, Visit Here

Take the Next Step

If you are passionate about global development, infrastructure, and international collaboration, these internships at the U.S. Trade and Development Agency provide a valuable platform to launch your career.

Prepare your application materials early, tailor your resume to the role you’re applying for, and highlight your interest in international development and infrastructure.

Start your journey toward a global career today.

Discover more Internship opportunities Here.

item.content:encoded:
If you’re an ambitious university graduate or a student in your final year seeking world-class professional experience in European governance, transparency, public administration, or EU affairs – this is one of the most sought-after opportunities within EU institutions for career-minded individuals wanting to work at the heart of EU democratic accountability and public service.

Hosting Institution

European Ombudsman

Overview: What Is the European Ombudsman Traineeship?

𝐓𝐫𝐚𝐢𝐧𝐞𝐞𝐬𝐡𝐢𝐩𝐬
● Digital communication
● Case-handling
● Traineeship for persons with disabilities

𝐑𝐞𝐪𝐮𝐢𝐫𝐞𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐬
● Candidates should be nationals of a Member State of the European Union
● No previous paid traineeship or work contract in a European institution
● Bachelors degree as minimum, solid training on EU law

𝐃𝐞𝐭𝐚𝐢𝐥𝐬
Deadline: 13 and 31 March
Location: Brussels or Strasbourg
Compensation: approx. €1400/m

The European Ombudsman Traineeship Programme is a paid, full-time, one-year internship designed for recent university graduates who want hands-on experience inside a core European Union institution. The programme offers a unique opportunity to work directly on issues related to EU administration, transparency, accountability, citizens’ rights, and good governance.

Trainees are placed in either Brussels or Strasbourg, depending on the needs of the Office, and work under the direct supervision of senior EU officials, usually a Head of Unit or equivalent. The traineeship combines professional responsibility, structured supervision, mentoring, and exposure to the daily functioning of EU institutions.

This programme is particularly attractive for candidates interested in:

  • EU law and policy

  • Public administration

  • Human rights and accountability

  • European governance and institutional relations

  • Transparency and citizens’ complaints mechanisms

Aim of the Traineeship

The traineeship is intended to:

  • Provide practical, real-world experience within an EU institution

  • Allow trainees to build on academic knowledge through professional tasks

  • Develop skills in policy analysis, administration, communication, and institutional work

  • Promote understanding of how EU institutions interact with citizens

Each trainee works under:

  • A line manager who defines objectives

  • A mentor who supports daily integration and work

  • A structured evaluation system (mid-term and final assessment)

Duration of the Traineeship

  • Standard duration: 12 months (1 year)

  • Extension: Not possible

  • Exceptional cases: Shorter traineeships may be offered in the interest of the service

Start date is typically 1 September each year.

Who Can Apply? (Eligibility Criteria)

1. Nationality

Applicants must be:

  • Nationals of an EU Member State, OR

  • Nationals of an EU accession or candidate country

Eligible regions:

  • Europe (EU + EU candidate/accession countries)

2. Educational Qualifications

Applicants must:

  • Hold a minimum 3-year university degree (Bachelor’s level or equivalent)

  • Degree must be in a discipline specified in the relevant traineeship call

Fields commonly accepted include (depending on the call):

  • Law

  • Political Science

  • European Studies

  • International Relations

  • Public Administration

  • Social Sciences

  • Communication and related disciplines

3. Language Requirements

Applicants must have:

  • Thorough knowledge of one EU official language, and

  • Very good knowledge of another EU official language

English is mandatory, as it is the main working language of the European Ombudsman.

4. Prior EU Experience Restrictions

Applicants must NOT have:

  • Completed more than 8 consecutive weeks (or 2 months) of paid traineeship in any EU institution

  • Held any paid employment (temporary, contract, auxiliary, interim agent, SNE, MEP assistant, etc.) in an EU institution

This rule ensures fair access for first-time EU trainees.

Special Programme: Traineeships for Persons with Disabilities

The European Ombudsman runs a dedicated positive-action traineeship programme for candidates with disabilities.

Key Features

  • Separate annual call (usually February)

  • Candidates may apply simultaneously to general traineeships if eligible

  • Open to:

    • University graduates, or

    • Students in at least their third year of higher education

Additional Support

  • Reasonable accommodation at the workplace

  • Additional financial support of up to 50% of the monthly grant to cover disability-related costs

  • Disability-related income does not reduce the traineeship grant

Applicants must provide official proof of disability in an EU official language.

Selection Procedure

Application Timeline

  • Call published: Normally February

  • Start date: 1 September

  • Final results communicated: By 30th June

Required Application Documents

All applications must be submitted via the online application system and include:

  1. Completed online application form

  2. CV in English

  3. Copies of diplomas/degrees (no certification or translation required)

  4. One-page motivation letter in English (required for some profiles)

● Incomplete applications are automatically rejected.

Selection Stages

  1. Eligibility and profile screening

  2. Written test (if applicable)

  3. Interview (video call or phone)

Selection is merit-based, with attention to:

  • Qualifications

  • Skills

  • Motivation

When candidates are equally qualified, the Office promotes:

  • Geographical balance

  • Gender equality

  • Inclusion of persons with disabilities

Financial Benefits and Allowances

Monthly Grant

  • Equivalent to 25% of the basic salary of an AD6 Step 1 EU official

  • Adjusted by:

    • Country weighting (Brussels or Strasbourg)

    • Household allowance (if applicable)

 The grant may be:

  • Reduced if the trainee receives other financial support

  • Adjusted due to salary indexation

Additional Financial Support

  • Case-by-case lump-sum assistance may be granted

  • Extra disability-related costs covered up to 50% of the monthly grant

Travel Cost Reimbursement

The Ombudsman reimburses travel costs at the beginning and end of the traineeship if not covered elsewhere.

Covered Travel Modes

  • Second-class train

  • Bus or car-sharing

  • Economy-class flight (for journeys over 500 km or sea crossings)

  • Private car (kilometric allowance)

– Tickets are usually booked by the Office
– Up to 50 kg of luggage may be reimbursed (with approval)

Insurance Coverage

  • Full sickness and accident insurance provided

  • Optional insurance for:

    • Spouse

    • Children (at the trainee’s expense)

Leave and Working Conditions

  • 2 working days of leave per month

  • No cash compensation for unused leave

  • Sick leave:

    • Medical certificate required after 3 days

  • Hybrid work rules apply

  • Strict confidentiality and ethics obligations

Supervision, Mentoring, and Evaluation

  • Initial objective-setting meeting

  • Mid-term performance review (6 months)

  • Final evaluation meeting

  • Dedicated mentor throughout the traineeship

  • Exit interview with Human Resources

Termination or Suspension

  • Either party may terminate the traineeship

  • One-month notice required for voluntary resignation

  • Grant payments stop during suspension

  • Due process applies in case of early termination

Legal Status of Trainees

  • Trainees are not EU officials or staff members

  • No automatic employment rights after completion

Data Protection

All personal data is processed under Regulation (EU) 2018/1725, ensuring high standards of privacy and data protection.

How to Apply

Applications must be submitted online via the official European Ombudsman website once the call is published (normally in February).

Important: Applicants may reapply in future years if unsuccessful.

Apply here

Key Deadlines (Typical Cycle)

  • Call opens: February

  • Application deadline: 13 and 31 March

  • Interviews/tests: Spring

  • Final decisions: By 30 June

  • Traineeship starts: 1 September

Why This Traineeship Is Highly Valuable

  • Paid, long-term EU institutional experience

  • Direct exposure to EU governance and citizens’ rights

  • Strong CV value for EU careers, NGOs, public policy, and law

  • Inclusive programme with strong disability support

  • Work in Brussels or Strasbourg, the heart of Europe

The European Ombudsman Traineeship is more than just an internship — it’s a gateway to public service, advancing democratic accountability and citizen rights within the EU. You’ll gain practical EU-level work experience, expand your professional network, and earn credentials that can propel careers in governance, policy, law, human rights, and international relations.

For more information visit here

For more global opportunities click here

The UNOY Internship 2025 is now open for applications for the Partnerships Officer position at UNOY Peacebuilders in The Hague, Netherlands. This UNOY Internship offers young professionals a valuable opportunity to gain hands-on experience in peacebuilding, fundraising, and partnership development within an international youth-led organization. Applications for the UNOY Internship close on 9 March 2025 at 23:59 CET, and selected candidates will participate in a six-month internship beginning on 28 April 2025.

About the UNOY Internship Program

The UNOY Internship at UNOY Peacebuilders provides young professionals with practical experience in the field of international peacebuilding and development. UNOY Peacebuilders is a global youth-led network consisting of more than 100 youth organizations across over 70 countries working together to promote peace, inclusion, and youth participation.

Through the UNOY Internship, interns join a dynamic international team and contribute to real projects that support youth-led peacebuilding initiatives worldwide. Interns work alongside experienced professionals while building skills in fundraising, partnerships, research, communications, and project coordination.

The UNOY Internship allows participants to expand their professional networks and gain experience within the international development and peacebuilding sectors.

UNOY Internship Responsibilities

During the UNOY Internship, the selected Partnerships Officer intern will work closely with the Partnership Coordinator and other team members to support various fundraising and partnership initiatives.

Fundraising and Partnership Development

One key component of the UNOY Internship is supporting the organization’s fundraising strategy and building relationships with partners and donors.

Intern responsibilities include:

  • Supporting the implementation of UNOY’s fundraising strategy
  • Researching potential donors and funding opportunities
  • Identifying funding priorities and entry points for new partnerships
  • Assisting in drafting concept notes and grant proposals
  • Supporting relationship management with donors and partner organizations
  • Contributing to reporting and grant management processes

These activities provide interns with valuable experience in proposal writing and partnership management within the nonprofit sector.

Financial Support to UNOY Members

Another important component of the UNOY Internship involves supporting the Financial Support to UNOY Members (FSUM) program. This initiative provides small grants to youth-led organizations within the UNOY network.

Intern responsibilities within this program include:

  • Supporting the management and implementation of the FSUM program
  • Assisting with grant monitoring and reporting processes
  • Preparing fundraising alerts highlighting funding opportunities for UNOY members
  • Supporting monitoring, evaluation, and learning activities

Through this work, interns gain insight into grant management and youth funding programs.

Communications and Administrative Support

The UNOY Internship also includes communications and administrative responsibilities that support the organization’s partnership and program activities.

Intern tasks may include:

  • Producing and editing content for UNOY’s website and social media channels
  • Supporting communications related to partnership initiatives
  • Assisting with planning major meetings such as the Annual Regional Coordinators and International Steering Group meeting
  • Providing general office support where necessary

These activities help interns develop strong communication and project coordination skills.

Benefits of the UNOY Internship

The UNOY Internship provides a range of benefits that support both professional development and practical experience in international development.

Benefits include:

  • A monthly stipend of 500 EUR
  • Travel reimbursement for commuting to the office
  • Hybrid work with the possibility of working remotely two days per week
  • Opportunities to gain experience in international development and peacebuilding
  • Access to mentorship and supervision from experienced professionals
  • Networking opportunities with organizations and partners across the world

The UNOY Internship also serves as a stepping stone for future careers in international organizations, government institutions, academia, and nonprofit development sectors.

Eligibility for the UNOY Internship

To apply for the UNOY Internship, candidates must meet several requirements related to education, location, and experience.

Applicants should have:

  • A degree in peace and conflict studies, international relations, or a related field
  • Strong interest in peacebuilding and youth leadership
  • Excellent English speaking and writing skills
  • Experience with data management tools and spreadsheets
  • Strong project management and organizational skills
  • Ability to work independently and within multicultural teams

Knowledge of additional languages such as French, Arabic, Spanish, or Dutch is considered an advantage.

Applicants must also meet legal requirements for working in the Netherlands, including being a resident of the Netherlands or a citizen of the European Union.

Location and Working Conditions

The UNOY Internship is based in The Hague, Netherlands, a global hub for international organizations and peace institutions.

The internship includes:

  • A six-month duration
  • A four-day work week (Monday to Thursday) totaling 32 hours per week
  • Hybrid working arrangements with two remote workdays per week

Interns must also have access to a personal computer and secure internet connection.

How to Apply for the UNOY Internship

Candidates interested in the UNOY Internship must apply through the official online application form provided by UNOY.

Applicants will be required to submit:

  • A CV
  • Answers to several short questions about their motivation and skills (maximum 250 words each)

Applicants experiencing technical issues with the application form may contact the UNOY team directly via email.

APPLY HERE

Deadline

The UNOY Internship application deadline is March 9, 2025 at 23:59 CET.

Because applications are reviewed on a rolling basis, candidates are encouraged to apply as early as possible.

Final Note

The UNOY Internship offers a valuable opportunity for young professionals interested in peacebuilding, international development, and youth leadership to gain real-world experience in a global organization. By participating in this internship, candidates can develop critical skills, contribute to meaningful peace initiatives, and build networks across the international development community.

item.content:encoded:
The Harper Fellowship 2026–2027 at The 19th is now accepting applications from emerging journalists interested in developing their careers in reporting, audience engagement, news product development, and nonprofit media leadership. The Harper Fellowship application deadline is March 20, 2026 at 5:00 p.m. PST, and the program offers a year-long salaried fellowship with full benefits and extensive professional development opportunities.

About the Harper Fellowship Program

The Harper Fellowship at The 19th is a prestigious journalism fellowship named after Frances Ellen Watkins Harper, widely recognized as the “mother of African-American journalism.” The program was launched in 2022 to create meaningful opportunities for graduates and alumni connected to Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) to gain experience in nonprofit journalism.

Through the Harper Fellowship program, selected fellows spend a full year working with The 19th’s editorial, product, audience engagement, and development teams. Fellows are embedded in their respective departments and contribute to meaningful journalism projects while gaining hands-on newsroom experience.

The Harper Fellowship focuses on strengthening diversity in journalism while providing fellows with mentorship, professional training, and career guidance that supports their long-term success in the media industry.

Harper Fellowship Tracks and Learning Areas

The Harper Fellowship program includes several fellowship tracks that allow participants to specialize in different areas of journalism and media operations.

The fellowship tracks include:

  • Reporting
  • Audience engagement
  • News product
  • Development (new track)

Reporting Track

Fellows in the reporting track gain experience covering stories through in-depth reporting and investigative work. Participants work closely with editors and journalists to produce original reporting that focuses on the intersection of gender, politics, and policy.

Reporting fellows are encouraged to develop their own story ideas, collaborate with newsroom teams, and experiment with storytelling across digital platforms.

Audience Engagement Track

The audience engagement track focuses on helping fellows develop skills in digital storytelling and audience-centered journalism. Participants learn how to distribute journalism across multiple platforms such as websites, social media, newsletters, and search engines.

This track also involves creating engaging social media content and collaborating with editorial and creative teams to produce compelling headlines, visuals, and storytelling formats.

News Product Track

The Harper Fellowship news product track introduces fellows to product design and innovation in journalism. Participants learn how to develop features and digital tools that improve audience experience and support newsroom goals.

Fellows work with product and technology teams to test ideas, analyze user feedback, and contribute to the development of journalism products such as newsletters, digital platforms, and audience engagement tools.

Development Track

The newly introduced Harper Fellowship development track focuses on the business and fundraising side of nonprofit journalism. Fellows gain hands-on experience in donor engagement, membership campaigns, and fundraising strategy.

Participants also learn how nonprofit news organizations sustain independent journalism through diversified revenue models and community support.

Benefits of the Harper Fellowship

The Harper Fellowship provides a comprehensive support system designed to help fellows build long-term careers in journalism.

Key benefits include:

  • A full-time salaried fellowship with benefits
  • One year of mentorship and professional development
  • Career coaching and job placement support
  • Networking opportunities with media professionals
  • Membership in the National Association of Black Journalists
  • Attendance at the NABJ convention and career fair
  • Access to journalism training workshops and seminars
  • A professional development stipend
  • A work-from-home stipend and wellness stipend
  • An Apple MacBook laptop provided for the fellowship year

These resources ensure fellows receive both financial and professional support throughout the program.

Harper Fellowship Professional Development

A major component of the Harper Fellowship program is its strong emphasis on professional growth.

Fellows participate in training workshops and development sessions covering topics such as:

  • Networking and career advancement
  • Salary negotiation
  • Resume and portfolio building
  • Mental health and burnout prevention
  • Financial literacy
  • Media industry insights from experienced journalists

The program also includes career coaching and mentorship to help fellows transition successfully into long-term journalism careers after completing the fellowship.

Harper Fellowship Retreats and Networking

The Harper Fellowship experience includes several retreats and networking events designed to connect fellows with media professionals and industry leaders.

The fellowship year begins with an opening retreat that introduces new fellows to the program and provides opportunities to connect with previous fellowship cohorts.

Midway through the fellowship, participants attend a career development retreat focused on networking and preparing for future opportunities in journalism.

Fellows also attend an annual staff retreat with The 19th team, allowing them to engage in strategic discussions, professional learning sessions, and collaborative activities.

These events help fellows build meaningful professional relationships and expand their journalism networks.

How to Apply for the Harper Fellowship

Applicants interested in the Harper Fellowship 2026–2027 must submit an application through The 19th’s official application platform.

The application typically requires:

  1. A cover letter explaining interest in the fellowship and career goals
  2. A resume outlining relevant experience
  3. Work samples demonstrating journalism or related skills

Applicants should clearly describe how the Harper Fellowship aligns with their career aspirations and how they plan to contribute to public-service journalism.

APPLY HERE

Deadline

Applications for the Harper Fellowship 2026–2027 must be submitted before the official deadline.

Application Deadline: March 20, 2026 (5:00 p.m. PST)

Applicants are encouraged to submit their materials early to avoid last-minute technical issues.

Final Note

The Harper Fellowship offers a unique opportunity for emerging journalists to gain hands-on newsroom experience while working alongside experienced media professionals. Through mentorship, professional training, and networking opportunities, the program equips fellows with the tools they need to build impactful careers in journalism.

For individuals passionate about storytelling, public-service journalism, and media innovation, the Harper Fellowship can serve as a powerful launchpad for a long-term career in the industry.

For more fellowships, scholarships, internships, and leadership programs, click here.

item.content:encoded:
Overview

Applications are now open for the World Heritage Young Professionals Forum 2026, a fully funded international programme organized within the framework of the UNESCO World Heritage Education Programme.

Hosted by the Republic of Korea through the Korea Heritage Service (KHS) and the Korean National Commission for UNESCO (KNCU), the forum will take place from 13–21 July 2026 alongside the 48th Session of the World Heritage Committee.

Under the theme “World Heritage, Communities and Education: Empowering Youth as Agents of Change,” the programme will bring together 30 young professionals from around the world to strengthen their knowledge, skills, and engagement in the protection and management of natural and cultural World Heritage sites.

Forum Theme and Objectives

The 2026 forum focuses on the relationship between World Heritage, communities, and education, with the goal of empowering youth to play an active role in heritage conservation and governance.

Key objectives include:

  • Strengthening the commitment and professional capacity of young practitioners working in heritage-related fields

  • Exploring how community participation can improve conservation and management practices

  • Examining the role of education, research, and learning in informed decision-making

  • Promoting youth leadership and inclusive governance in World Heritage protection

Through exchanges with local and international experts, participants will engage in collaborative learning and develop practical perspectives on sustainable heritage management.

Programme Structure

The forum combines academic discussions with practical, site-based learning experiences at World Heritage properties in the Republic of Korea. Activities include:

  • Thematic presentations and expert-led discussions

  • Collaborative workshops and group work

  • Site visits and field-based learning

  • Peer exchange with international participants

  • Joint session with the World Heritage Site Managers Forum

At the conclusion of the programme, participants will collectively prepare and present a Youth Declaration to the 48th Session of the World Heritage Committee.

Provisional Schedule

  • 12 July 2026: Arrival of participants

  • 13 July 2026: Opening of the forum and introductions

  • 14–19 July 2026: Thematic sessions, workshops, and site-based learning

  • 18 July 2026: Joint session with the World Heritage Site Managers Forum

  • 19 July 2026: Drafting of the Youth Declaration

  • 20 July 2026: Finalisation and presentation of the Youth Declaration

  • 21 July 2026: Closing session and departure

Eligibility Criteria

Applicants must meet the following requirements:

Age

  • Between 23 and 32 years old (born between 1994 and 2003 inclusive)

Professional Profile

Applicants should be young professionals or practitioners engaged in one or more of the following areas:

  • Education and teaching in formal learning settings

  • World Heritage site management

  • Research and innovation related to World Heritage

  • NGOs or community-level associations focused on heritage

Additional Requirements

  • Demonstrated involvement in World Heritage-related activities

  • Strong motivation to contribute to discussions on youth, communities, and education

  • Full availability for the entire duration of the forum

  • Proficiency in English (the working language of the programme)

Selection Considerations

The selection process aims to ensure:

  • Balanced geographical representation

  • Gender equality

  • Diversity of professional backgrounds

  • Potential for knowledge-sharing and impact after the forum

Funding and Benefits

The World Heritage Young Professionals Forum 2026 is fully funded. Selected participants will receive:

  • International economy-class travel

  • Accommodation

  • Local transportation

  • Meals during the programme

  • Visa support and related fees where applicable

Participants wishing to extend their stay after the programme must cover additional expenses independently.

Application Process

Interested candidates must apply through the official online application form:

Application Link: https://unesco-2023.limesurvey.net/662537

Application Deadline: 15 March 2026 (23:59 CET)

Important notes:

  • Only complete applications submitted through the online form will be considered

  • Selection is based solely on the information provided in the application

  • Recommendations or endorsements are not required

Selected applicants will be notified via email.

Contact Information

For questions regarding the application process:

Email: For any questions, kindly contact: wh-ypf@unesco.org

Why You Should Apply

The World Heritage Young Professionals Forum is a flagship initiative of UNESCO’s World Heritage Education Programme. It offers young professionals a unique opportunity to:

  • Build international networks with peers and experts

  • Gain practical experience through site-based learning

  • Deepen understanding of the World Heritage Convention

  • Contribute directly to global discussions on heritage conservation

  • Strengthen leadership skills in community-based and sustainable heritage management

For professionals working at the intersection of heritage, education, and community engagement, the forum provides both international exposure and long-term professional value.

Call for Applications

Selection of participants will be carried out solely on the basis of the online applications, in accordance with the criteria specified in the Call for Applications. Recommendations, nominations, or endorsements will therefore not be considered.

 

Online application

Applications must be submitted through the online application form by 15 March 2026 at 23:59 CET

Application Link: https://unesco-2023.limesurvey.net/662537

For any questions, kindly contact: wh-ypf@unesco.org

For more info please visit: https://whc.unesco.org/en/news/2862/

item.content:encoded:
The third cohort of the MENA Scholars Fellowship (MSF) is now open for applications, offering a unique opportunity for early-career economists and researchers from the Middle East and North Africa to gain hands-on experience in rigorous impact evaluation and policy-relevant research.

Launched by J-PAL Middle East and North Africa in partnership with Egypt Impact Lab, the fellowship is a prestigious two-year program designed to strengthen local research capacity and deepen evidence-based policymaking across the MENA region.

About the MENA Scholars Fellowship

The MENA Scholars Fellowship creates a structured pathway for researchers to design, implement, and contribute to randomized evaluations addressing poverty reduction and social development challenges. Fellows work closely with J-PAL-affiliated researchers, receive tailored mentorship, and participate in advanced training that blends academic rigor with real-world policy impact.

Each selected fellow receives a USD 15,000 stipend over the two-year period to support active participation in fellowship activities.

What Fellows Will Gain

Over the course of the fellowship, scholars will benefit from a comprehensive program that includes:

  • Hands-on randomized evaluations alongside J-PAL affiliates, J-PAL MENA staff, and implementing partners

  • One-on-one mentorship from senior researchers and scientific directors

  • Access to regional and global research networks, including other Scholars Fellowship cohorts worldwide

  • Advanced training, including completion of two MIT MicroMasters online courses focused on impact evaluation and econometric analysis

  • Capacity-building workshops on proposal writing, technical research skills, and professional development

  • Media and policy engagement support to amplify research findings

  • Participation in regional policy events and presentations with leading academics

  • An independent evaluation design project in the second year, guided by expert mentors

Information Webinar

To help prospective applicants better understand the fellowship, an information webinar will be held on Thursday, March 05, 2026, from 11:00 am to 12:00 pm Cairo local time. The session will cover eligibility requirements, the application process, and insights from previous fellows.

Interested candidates can register via the official webinar registration form. After registration, participants will receive a Google Calendar invitation with the webinar link and event details.

Application Timeline

  • Application deadline: March 26, 2026, at 11:59 pm Cairo Local Time

  • Shortlisting notification: Mid-April 2026

  • Final interviews: Mid-May 2026

  • Fellowship start date: By June 2026

APPLY HERE. 

For more information about this apportunity, click here. 

Discover more fellowship opportunities here. 

Applicants must submit an online application form along with a resume and a motivation-focused cover letter. Shortlisted candidates will advance to a second application phase, which includes additional written questions and a short recorded video.

Funding and Institutional Support

The fellowship is supported by Community Jameel and the Sawiris Foundation for Social Development, reinforcing a shared commitment to strengthening evidence-based policy research in the MENA region.

For complete fellowship details, eligibility criteria, and access to the application form, applicants are encouraged to visit the official MENA Scholars Fellowship webpage.
